refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: GObject is the fundamental type providing the common attributes and methods for all object types in GTK+, Pango and other libraries based on GObject. The GObject class provides methods for object construction and destruction, property access methods, and signal support. Signals are described in detail here.

For a tutorial on implementing a new GObject class, see How to define and implement a new GObject. For a list of naming conventions for GObjects and their methods, see the GType conventions. For the high-level concepts behind GObject, read Instantiable classed types: Objects.

refsect3.title: Floating references
refsect3.para: GInitiallyUnowned is derived from GObject. The only difference between the two is that the initial reference of a GInitiallyUnowned is flagged as a "floating" reference. This means that it is not specifically claimed to be "owned" by any code portion. The main motivation for providing floating references is C convenience. In particular, it allows code to be written as:

If container_add_child() calls g_object_ref_sink() on the passed-in child, no reference of the newly created child is leaked. Without floating references, container_add_child() can only g_object_ref() the new child, so to implement this code without reference leaks, it would have to be written as:

The floating reference can be converted into an ordinary reference by calling g_object_ref_sink(). For already sunken objects (objects that don't have a floating reference anymore), g_object_ref_sink() is equivalent to g_object_ref() and returns a new reference.

Since floating references are useful almost exclusively for C convenience, language bindings that provide automated reference and memory ownership maintenance (such as smart pointers or garbage collection) should not expose floating references in their API.
Some object implementations may need to save an objects floating state across certain code portions (an example is GtkMenu), to achieve this, the following sequence can be used:

refsect2.title: GObjectGetPropertyFunc ()
refsect2.para: The type of the get_property function of GObjectClass.

entry.para: the numeric id under which the property was registered with g_object_class_install_property().
a GValue to return the property value in

refsect2.title: GObjectSetPropertyFunc ()
refsect2.para: The type of the set_property function of GObjectClass.

entry.para: the numeric id under which the property was registered with g_object_class_install_property().
the new value for the property

refsect2.title: GObjectFinalizeFunc ()
refsect2.para: The type of the finalize function of GObjectClass.

refsect2.title: G_TYPE_IS_OBJECT()
refsect2.para: Check if the passed in type id is a G_TYPE_OBJECT or derived from it.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: FALSE or TRUE, indicating whether type is a G_TYPE_OBJECT.

refsect2.title: G_OBJECT()
refsect2.para: Casts a GObject or derived pointer into a (GObject*) pointer. Depending on the current debugging level, this function may invoke certain runtime checks to identify invalid casts.

entry.para: Object which is subject to casting.

refsect2.title: G_IS_OBJECT()
refsect2.para: Checks whether a valid GTypeInstance pointer is of type G_TYPE_OBJECT.

entry.para: Instance to check for being a G_TYPE_OBJECT.

refsect2.title: G_OBJECT_CLASS()
refsect2.para: Casts a derived GObjectClass structure into a GObjectClass structure.

refsect2.title: G_IS_OBJECT_CLASS()
refsect2.para: Checks whether class "is a" valid GObjectClass structure of type G_TYPE_OBJECT or derived.

refsect2.title: G_OBJECT_GET_CLASS()
refsect2.para: Get the class structure associated to a GObject instance.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: pointer to object class structure.

refsect2.title: G_OBJECT_TYPE()
refsect2.para: Get the type id of an object.

entry.para: Object to return the type id for.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: Type id of object .

refsect2.title: G_OBJECT_TYPE_NAME()
refsect2.para: Get the name of an object's type.

entry.para: Object to return the type name for.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: Type name of object . The string is owned by the type system and should not be freed.

refsect2.title: G_OBJECT_CLASS_TYPE()
refsect2.para: Get the type id of a class structure.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: Type id of class .

refsect2.title: G_OBJECT_CLASS_NAME()
refsect2.para: Return the name of a class structure's type.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: Type name of class . The string is owned by the type system and should not be freed.

refsect2.title: g_object_class_install_property ()
refsect2.para: Installs a new property.

All properties should be installed during the class initializer. It is possible to install properties after that, but doing so is not recommend, and specifically, is not guaranteed to be thread-safe vs. use of properties on the same type on other threads.

Note that it is possible to redefine a property in a derived class, by installing a property with the same name. This can be useful at times, e.g. to change the range of allowed values or the default value.

entry.para: the id for the new property
the GParamSpec for the new property

refsect2.title: g_object_class_install_properties ()
refsect2.para: Installs new properties from an array of GParamSpecs.

All properties should be installed during the class initializer. It is possible to install properties after that, but doing so is not recommend, and specifically, is not guaranteed to be thread-safe vs. use of properties on the same type on other threads.
The property id of each property is the index of each GParamSpec in the pspecs array.
The property id of 0 is treated specially by GObject and it should not be used to store a GParamSpec.
allows calling g_object_notify_by_pspec() to notify of property changes:

entry.para: the length of the GParamSpecs array
the GParamSpecs array defining the new properties.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.26

refsect2.title: g_object_class_find_property ()
refsect2.para: Looks up the GParamSpec for a property of a class.

entry.para: the name of the property to look up

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the GParamSpec for the property, or NULL if the class doesn't have a property of that name.

refsect2.title: g_object_class_list_properties ()
refsect2.para: Get an array of GParamSpec* for all properties of a class.

entry.para: return location for the length of the returned array.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: an array of GParamSpec* which should be freed after use.

refsect2.title: g_object_class_override_property ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_object_class_override_property (GObjectClass *oclass, guint property_id, const gchar *name);
refsect2.para: Registers property_id as referring to a property with the name name in a parent class or in an interface implemented by oclass . This allows this class to "override" a property implementation in a parent class or to provide the implementation of a property from an interface.

Internally, overriding is implemented by creating a property of type GParamSpecOverride; generally operations that query the properties of the object class, such as g_object_class_find_property() or g_object_class_list_properties() will return the overridden property. However, in one case, the construct_properties argument of the constructor virtual function, the GParamSpecOverride is passed instead, so that the param_id field of the GParamSpec will be correct. For virtually all uses, this makes no difference. If you need to get the overridden property, you can call g_param_spec_get_redirect_target().

entry.para: the name of a property registered in a parent class or in an interface of this class.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.4

refsect2.title: g_object_interface_install_property ()
refsect2.para: Add a property to an interface; this is only useful for interfaces that are added to GObject-derived types. Adding a property to an interface forces all objects classes with that interface to have a compatible property. The compatible property could be a newly created GParamSpec, but normally g_object_class_override_property() will be used so that the object class only needs to provide an implementation and inherits the property description, default value, bounds, and so forth from the interface property.

This function is meant to be called from the interface's default vtable initialization function (the class_init member of GTypeInfo.) It must not be called after after class_init has been called for any object types implementing this interface.
If pspec is a floating reference, it will be consumed.

entry.para: any interface vtable for the interface, or the default vtable for the interface.
the GParamSpec for the new property

refsect2.para: Since: 2.4

refsect2.title: g_object_interface_find_property ()
refsect2.para:
Find the GParamSpec with the given name for an interface. Generally, the interface vtable passed in as g_iface
will be the default vtable from g_type_default_interface_ref(), or, if you know the interface has already been loaded, g_type_default_interface_peek().

entry.para: any interface vtable for the interface, or the default vtable for the interface.
name of a property to lookup.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the GParamSpec for the property of the interface with the name property_name , or NULL if no such property exists.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.4

refsect2.title: g_object_interface_list_properties ()
refsect2.para: Lists the properties of an interface.Generally, the interface vtable passed in as g_iface will be the default vtable from g_type_default_interface_ref(), or, if you know the interface has already been loaded, g_type_default_interface_peek().

entry.para: any interface vtable for the interface, or the default vtable for the interface.
location to store number of properties returned.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: a pointer to an array of pointers to GParamSpec structures. The paramspecs are owned by GLib, but the array should be freed with g_free() when you are done with it.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.4

refsect2.title: g_object_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new instance of a GObject subtype and sets its properties.
Construction parameters (see G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT, G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT_ONLY) which are not explicitly specified are set to their default values.

entry.para: the type id of the GObject subtype to instantiate
the name of the first property
the value of the first property, followed optionally by more name/value pairs, followed by NULL

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: a new instance of object_type .

refsect2.title: g_object_new_with_properties ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new instance of a GObject subtype and sets its properties using the provided arrays. Both arrays must have exactly n_properties elements, and the names and values correspond by index.
Construction parameters (see G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT, G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT_ONLY) which are not explicitly specified are set to their default values.

entry.para: the names of each property to be set.
the values of each property to be set.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: a new instance of object_type .

refsect2.para: Since: 2.54

refsect2.title: g_object_newv ()
refsect2.programlisting: gpointer g_object_newv (GType object_type, guint n_parameters, GParameter *parameters);

warning.para: g_object_newv has been deprecated since version 2.54 and should not be used in newly-written code.
Use g_object_new_with_properties() instead. deprecated. See GParameter for more information.

refsect2.para: Creates a new instance of a GObject subtype and sets its properties.
Construction parameters (see G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT, G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT_ONLY) which are not explicitly specified are set to their default values.

entry.para: the type id of the GObject subtype to instantiate
the length of the parameters array

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: a new instance of object_type .

refsect2.title: g_object_ref ()
refsect2.para: Increases the reference count of object .

Since GLib 2.56, if GLIB_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED is 2.56 or greater, the type of object will be propagated to the return type (using the GCC typeof() extension), so any casting the caller needs to do on the return type must be explicit.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the same object .

refsect2.title: g_object_unref ()
refsect2.para: Decreases the reference count of object . When its reference count drops to 0, the object is finalized (i.e. its memory is freed).

If the pointer to the GObject may be reused in future (for example, if it is an instance variable of another object), it is recommended to clear the pointer to NULL rather than retain a dangling pointer to a potentially invalid GObject instance. Use g_clear_object() for this.

refsect2.title: g_object_ref_sink ()
refsect2.para: Increase the reference count of object , and possibly remove the floating reference, if object has a floating reference.

In other words, if the object is floating, then this call "assumes ownership" of the floating reference, converting it to a normal reference by clearing the floating flag while leaving the reference count unchanged. If the object is not floating, then this call adds a new normal reference increasing the reference count by one.
Since GLib 2.56, the type of object will be propagated to the return type under the same conditions as for g_object_ref().

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: object .

refsect2.para: Since: 2.10

refsect2.title: g_set_object()
refsect2.para: Updates a GObject pointer to refer to new_object . It increments the reference count of new_object (if non-NULL), decrements the reference count of the current value of object_ptr (if non-NULL), and assigns new_object to object_ptr . The assignment is not atomic.
object_ptr must not be NULL.
A macro is also included that allows this function to be used without pointer casts. The function itself is static inline, so its address may vary between compilation units.
One convenient usage of this function is in implementing property setters:

entry.para: a pointer to a GObject reference
a pointer to the new GObject to assign to it, or NULL to clear the pointer.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: TRUE if the value of object_ptr changed, FALSE otherwise

refsect2.para: Since: 2.44

refsect2.title: g_clear_object ()
refsect2.para: Clears a reference to a GObject.
object_ptr must not be NULL.
If the reference is NULL then this function does nothing. Otherwise, the reference count of the object is decreased and the pointer is set to NULL.
A macro is also included that allows this function to be used without pointer casts.

entry.para: a pointer to a GObject reference

refsect2.para: Since: 2.28

refsect2.title: g_object_is_floating ()
refsect2.para: Checks whether object has a floating reference.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: TRUE if object has a floating reference

refsect2.para: Since: 2.10

refsect2.title: g_object_force_floating ()
refsect2.para: This function is intended for GObject implementations to re-enforce a floating object reference. Doing this is seldom required: all GInitiallyUnowneds are created with a floating reference which usually just needs to be sunken by calling g_object_ref_sink().
Since: 2.10

refsect2.title: GWeakNotify ()
refsect2.para: A GWeakNotify function can be added to an object as a callback that gets triggered when the object is finalized. Since the object is already being finalized when the GWeakNotify is called, there's not much you could do with the object, apart from e.g. using its address as hash-index or the like.

entry.para: data that was provided when the weak reference was established

refsect2.title: g_object_weak_ref ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_object_weak_ref (GObject *object, GWeakNotify notify, gpointer data);
refsect2.para: Adds a weak reference callback to an object. Weak references are used for notification when an object is finalized. They are called "weak references" because they allow you to safely hold a pointer to an object without calling g_object_ref() (g_object_ref() adds a strong reference, that is, forces the object to stay alive).

Note that the weak references created by this method are not thread-safe: they cannot safely be used in one thread if the object's last g_object_unref() might happen in another thread. Use GWeakRef if thread-safety is required.

entry.para: callback to invoke before the object is freed
extra data to pass to notify

refsect2.title: g_object_weak_unref ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_object_weak_unref (GObject *object, GWeakNotify notify, gpointer data);
refsect2.para: Removes a weak reference callback to an object.

entry.para: GObject to remove a weak reference from

refsect2.title: g_object_add_weak_pointer ()
refsect2.para: Adds a weak reference from weak_pointer to object to indicate that the pointer located at weak_pointer_location is only valid during the lifetime of object . When the object is finalized, weak_pointer will be set to NULL.

Note that as with g_object_weak_ref(), the weak references created by this method are not thread-safe: they cannot safely be used in one thread if the object's last g_object_unref() might happen in another thread. Use GWeakRef if thread-safety is required.

entry.para: The object that should be weak referenced.
The memory address of a pointer.

refsect2.title: g_object_remove_weak_pointer ()
refsect2.para: Removes a weak reference from object that was previously added using g_object_add_weak_pointer(). The weak_pointer_location has to match the one used with g_object_add_weak_pointer().

entry.para: The object that is weak referenced.
The memory address of a pointer.

refsect2.title: g_set_weak_pointer()
refsect2.para:
Updates a pointer to weakly refer to new_object . It assigns new_object
to weak_pointer_location and ensures that weak_pointer_location will automaticaly be set to NULL if new_object gets destroyed. The assignment is not atomic. The weak reference is not thread-safe, see g_object_add_weak_pointer() for details.
weak_pointer_location must not be NULL.
A macro is also included that allows this function to be used without pointer casts. The function itself is static inline, so its address may vary between compilation units.
One convenient usage of this function is in implementing property setters:

entry.para: the memory address of a pointer
a pointer to the new GObject to assign to it, or NULL to clear the pointer.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: TRUE if the value of weak_pointer_location changed, FALSE otherwise

refsect2.para: Since: 2.56

refsect2.title: g_clear_weak_pointer()
refsect2.para: Clears a weak reference to a GObject.
weak_pointer_location must not be NULL.
If the weak reference is NULL then this function does nothing. Otherwise, the weak reference to the object is removed for that location and the pointer is set to NULL.
A macro is also included that allows this function to be used without pointer casts. The function itself is static inline, so its address may vary between compilation units.

entry.para: The memory address of a pointer

refsect2.para: Since: 2.56

refsect2.title: GToggleNotify ()
refsect2.para: A callback function used for notification when the state of a toggle reference changes. See g_object_add_toggle_ref().

entry.para: The object on which g_object_add_toggle_ref() was called.
TRUE if the toggle reference is now the last reference to the object. FALSE if the toggle reference was the last reference and there are now other references.

refsect2.title: g_object_add_toggle_ref ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_object_add_toggle_ref (GObject *object, GToggleNotify notify, gpointer data);
refsect2.para: Increases the reference count of the object by one and sets a callback to be called when all other references to the object are dropped, or when this is already the last reference to the object and another reference is established.

This functionality is intended for binding object to a proxy object managed by another memory manager. This is done with two paired references: the strong reference added by g_object_add_toggle_ref() and a reverse reference to the proxy object which is either a strong reference or weak reference.

The setup is that when there are no other references to object , only a weak reference is held in the reverse direction from object
to the proxy object, but when there are other references held to object , a strong reference is held. The notify callback is called when the reference from object to the proxy object should be "toggled" from strong to weak (is_last_ref true) or weak to strong (is_last_ref false).
Since a (normal) reference must be held to the object before calling g_object_add_toggle_ref(), the initial state of the reverse link is always strong.

Multiple toggle references may be added to the same gobject, however if there are multiple toggle references to an object, none of them will ever be notified until all but one are removed. For this reason, you should only ever use a toggle reference if there is important state in the proxy object.

entry.para: a function to call when this reference is the last reference to the object, or is no longer the last reference.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.8

refsect2.title: g_object_remove_toggle_ref ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_object_remove_toggle_ref (GObject *object, GToggleNotify notify, gpointer data);
refsect2.para: Removes a reference added with g_object_add_toggle_ref(). The reference count of the object is decreased by one.

entry.para: a function to call when this reference is the last reference to the object, or is no longer the last reference.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.8

refsect2.title: g_object_connect ()
refsect2.para: A convenience function to connect multiple signals at once.
The signal specs expected by this function have the form "modifier::signal_name", where modifier can be one of the following:

listitem.para: swapped-signal, swapped_signal: equivalent to g_signal_connect_data (..., NULL, G_CONNECT_SWAPPED)
swapped_object_signal, swapped-object-signal: equivalent to g_signal_connect_object (..., G_CONNECT_SWAPPED)
signal_after, signal-after: equivalent to g_signal_connect_data (..., NULL, G_CONNECT_AFTER)
object_signal_after, object-signal-after: equivalent to g_signal_connect_object (..., G_CONNECT_AFTER)
swapped_signal_after, swapped-signal-after: equivalent to g_signal_connect_data (..., NULL, G_CONNECT_SWAPPED | G_CONNECT_AFTER)
swapped_object_signal_after, swapped-object-signal-after: equivalent to g_signal_connect_object (..., G_CONNECT_SWAPPED | G_CONNECT_AFTER)

informalexample.programlisting: menu->toplevel = g_object_connect (g_object_new (GTK_TYPE_WINDOW, "type", GTK_WINDOW_POPUP, "child", menu, NULL), "signal::event", gtk_menu_window_event, menu, "signal::size_request", gtk_menu_window_size_request, menu, "signal::destroy", gtk_widget_destroyed, &menu->toplevel, NULL);

entry.para: the spec for the first signal
GCallback for the first signal, followed by data for the first signal, followed optionally by more signal spec/callback/data triples, followed by NULL

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: object .

refsect2.title: g_object_disconnect ()
refsect2.para: A convenience function to disconnect multiple signals at once.

The signal specs expected by this function have the form "any_signal", which means to disconnect any signal with matching callback and data, or "any_signal::signal_name", which only disconnects the signal named "signal_name".

entry.para: the spec for the first signal
GCallback for the first signal, followed by data for the first signal, followed optionally by more signal spec/callback/data triples, followed by NULL

refsect2.title: g_object_set ()
refsect2.para: Sets properties on an object.
Note that the "notify" signals are queued and only emitted (in reverse order) after all properties have been set. See g_object_freeze_notify().

entry.para: name of the first property to set
value for the first property, followed optionally by more name/value pairs, followed by NULL

refsect2.title: g_object_setv ()
refsect2.para: Sets n_properties properties for an object . Properties to be set will be taken from values . All properties must be valid. Warnings will be emitted and undefined behaviour may result if invalid properties are passed in.

entry.para: the names of each property to be set.
the values of each property to be set.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.54

refsect2.title: g_object_get ()
refsect2.para: Gets properties of an object.
In general, a copy is made of the property contents and the caller is responsible for freeing the memory in the appropriate manner for the type, for instance by calling g_free() or g_object_unref().
Here is an example of using g_object_get() to get the contents of three properties: an integer, a string and an object:

entry.para: name of the first property to get
return location for the first property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by NULL

refsect2.title: g_object_getv ()
refsect2.para: Gets n_properties properties for an object . Obtained properties will be set to values . All properties must be valid. Warnings will be emitted and undefined behaviour may result if invalid properties are passed in.

entry.para: the names of each property to get.
the values of each property to get.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.54

refsect2.title: g_object_notify ()
refsect2.para: Emits a "notify" signal for the property property_name on object .
When possible, eg. when signaling a property change from within the class that registered the property, you should use g_object_notify_by_pspec() instead.

Note that emission of the notify signal may be blocked with g_object_freeze_notify(). In this case, the signal emissions are queued and will be emitted (in reverse order) when g_object_thaw_notify() is called.

entry.para: the name of a property installed on the class of object .

refsect2.title: g_object_notify_by_pspec ()
refsect2.para: Emits a "notify" signal for the property specified by pspec on object .
This function omits the property name lookup, hence it is faster than g_object_notify().

One way to avoid using g_object_notify() from within the class that registered the properties, and using g_object_notify_by_pspec() instead, is to store the GParamSpec used with g_object_class_install_property() inside a static array, e.g.:
and then notify a change on the "foo" property with:

entry.para: the GParamSpec of a property installed on the class of object .

refsect2.para: Since: 2.26

refsect2.title: g_object_freeze_notify ()
refsect2.para: Increases the freeze count on object . If the freeze count is non-zero, the emission of "notify" signals on object is stopped. The signals are queued until the freeze count is decreased to zero. Duplicate notifications are squashed so that at most one notify signal is emitted for each property modified while the object is frozen.
This is necessary for accessors that modify multiple properties to prevent premature notification while the object is still being modified.

refsect2.title: g_object_thaw_notify ()
refsect2.para:
Reverts the effect of a previous call to g_object_freeze_notify(). The freeze count is decreased on object
and when it reaches zero, queued "notify" signals are emitted.
Duplicate notifications for each property are squashed so that at most one notify signal is emitted for each property, in the reverse order in which they have been queued.
It is an error to call this function when the freeze count is zero.

refsect2.title: g_object_get_data ()
refsect2.para: Gets a named field from the objects table of associations (see g_object_set_data()).

entry.para: name of the key for that association

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the data if found, or NULL if no such data exists.

refsect2.title: g_object_set_data ()
refsect2.para: Each object carries around a table of associations from strings to pointers. This function lets you set an association.
If the object already had an association with that name, the old association will be destroyed.

entry.para: data to associate with that key.

refsect2.title: g_object_set_data_full ()
refsect2.para: Like g_object_set_data() except it adds notification for when the association is destroyed, either by setting it to a different value or when the object is destroyed.
Note that the destroy callback is not called if data is NULL.

entry.para: data to associate with that key.
function to call when the association is destroyed.

refsect2.title: g_object_steal_data ()
refsect2.para: Remove a specified datum from the object's data associations, without invoking the association's destroy handler.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the data if found, or NULL if no such data exists.

refsect2.title: g_object_dup_data ()
refsect2.para: This is a variant of g_object_get_data() which returns a 'duplicate' of the value. dup_func defines the meaning of 'duplicate' in this context, it could e.g. take a reference on a ref-counted object.

If the key is not set on the object then dup_func
will be called with a NULL argument.

Note that dup_func is called while user data of object
is locked.
This function can be useful to avoid races when multiple threads are using object data on the same key on the same object.

entry.para: the GObject to store user data on
a string, naming the user data pointer

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the result of calling dup_func on the value associated with key on object , or NULL if not set. If dup_func is NULL, the value is returned unmodified.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.34

refsect2.title: g_object_replace_data ()
refsect2.programlisting: gboolean g_object_replace_data (GObject *object, const gchar *key, gpointer oldval, gpointer newval, GDestroyNotify destroy, GDestroyNotify *old_destroy);
refsect2.para: Compares the user data for the key key on object with oldval , and if they are the same, replaces oldval with newval .
This is like a typical atomic compare-and-exchange operation, for user data on an object.

If the previous value was replaced then ownership of the old value (oldval ) is passed to the caller, including the registered destroy notify for it (passed out in old_destroy ). Its up to the caller to free this as needed, which may or may not include using old_destroy as sometimes replacement should not destroy the object in the normal way.

entry.para: the GObject to store user data on
a string, naming the user data pointer
the old value to compare against.
a destroy notify for the new value.
destroy notify for the existing value.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: TRUE if the existing value for key was replaced by newval , FALSE otherwise.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.34

refsect2.title: g_object_get_qdata ()
refsect2.para: This function gets back user data pointers stored via g_object_set_qdata().

entry.para: The GObject to get a stored user data pointer from
A GQuark, naming the user data pointer

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: The user data pointer set, or NULL.

refsect2.title: g_object_set_qdata ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_object_set_qdata (GObject *object, GQuark quark, gpointer data);
refsect2.para: This sets an opaque, named pointer on an object. The name is specified through a GQuark (retrived e.g. via g_quark_from_static_string()), and the pointer can be gotten back from the object with g_object_get_qdata() until the object is finalized. Setting a previously set user data pointer, overrides (frees) the old pointer set, using NULL as pointer essentially removes the data stored.

entry.para: The GObject to set store a user data pointer
A GQuark, naming the user data pointer

refsect2.title: g_object_set_qdata_full ()
refsect2.programlisting: void g_object_set_qdata_full (GObject *object, GQuark quark, gpointer data, GDestroyNotify destroy);
refsect2.para: This function works like g_object_set_qdata(), but in addition, a void (*destroy) (gpointer) function may be specified which is called with data as argument when the object is finalized, or the data is being overwritten by a call to g_object_set_qdata() with the same quark .

entry.para: The GObject to set store a user data pointer
A GQuark, naming the user data pointer
Function to invoke with data as argument, when data needs to be freed.

refsect2.title: g_object_steal_qdata ()
refsect2.para: This function gets back user data pointers stored via g_object_set_qdata() and removes the data from object without invoking its destroy() function (if any was set). Usually, calling this function is only required to update user data pointers with a destroy notifier, for example:

Using g_object_get_qdata() in the above example, instead of g_object_steal_qdata() would have left the destroy function set, and thus the partial string list would have been freed upon g_object_set_qdata_full().

entry.para: The GObject to get a stored user data pointer from
A GQuark, naming the user data pointer

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: The user data pointer set, or NULL.

refsect2.title: g_object_dup_qdata ()
refsect2.programlisting: gpointer g_object_dup_qdata (GObject *object, GQuark quark, GDuplicateFunc dup_func, gpointer user_data);
refsect2.para: This is a variant of g_object_get_qdata() which returns a 'duplicate' of the value. dup_func defines the meaning of 'duplicate' in this context, it could e.g. take a reference on a ref-counted object.

If the quark is not set on the object then dup_func
will be called with a NULL argument.

Note that dup_func is called while user data of object
is locked.
This function can be useful to avoid races when multiple threads are using object data on the same key on the same object.

entry.para: the GObject to store user data on
a GQuark, naming the user data pointer

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the result of calling dup_func on the value associated with quark on object , or NULL if not set. If dup_func is NULL, the value is returned unmodified.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.34

refsect2.title: g_object_replace_qdata ()
refsect2.programlisting: gboolean g_object_replace_qdata (GObject *object, GQuark quark, gpointer oldval, gpointer newval, GDestroyNotify destroy, GDestroyNotify *old_destroy);
refsect2.para: Compares the user data for the key quark on object with oldval , and if they are the same, replaces oldval with newval .
This is like a typical atomic compare-and-exchange operation, for user data on an object.

If the previous value was replaced then ownership of the old value (oldval ) is passed to the caller, including the registered destroy notify for it (passed out in old_destroy ). Its up to the caller to free this as needed, which may or may not include using old_destroy as sometimes replacement should not destroy the object in the normal way.

entry.para: the GObject to store user data on
a GQuark, naming the user data pointer
the old value to compare against.
a destroy notify for the new value.
destroy notify for the existing value.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: TRUE if the existing value for quark was replaced by newval , FALSE otherwise.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.34

refsect2.title: g_object_set_property ()
refsect2.para: Sets a property on an object.

entry.para: the name of the property to set

refsect2.title: g_object_get_property ()
refsect2.para: Gets a property of an object. value must have been initialized to the expected type of the property (or a type to which the expected type can be transformed) using g_value_init().
In general, a copy is made of the property contents and the caller is responsible for freeing the memory by calling g_value_unset().
Note that g_object_get_property() is really intended for language bindings, g_object_get() is much more convenient for C programming.

entry.para: the name of the property to get
return location for the property value

refsect2.title: g_object_new_valist ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new instance of a GObject subtype and sets its properties.
Construction parameters (see G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT, G_PARAM_CONSTRUCT_ONLY) which are not explicitly specified are set to their default values.

entry.para: the type id of the GObject subtype to instantiate
the name of the first property
the value of the first property, followed optionally by more name/value pairs, followed by NULL

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: a new instance of object_type

refsect2.title: g_object_set_valist ()
refsect2.para: Sets properties on an object.

entry.para: name of the first property to set
value for the first property, followed optionally by more name/value pairs, followed by NULL

refsect2.title: g_object_get_valist ()
refsect2.para: Gets properties of an object.
In general, a copy is made of the property contents and the caller is responsible for freeing the memory in the appropriate manner for the type, for instance by calling g_free() or g_object_unref().
See g_object_get().

entry.para: name of the first property to get
return location for the first property, followed optionally by more name/return location pairs, followed by NULL

refsect2.title: g_object_watch_closure ()
refsect2.para: This function essentially limits the life time of the closure to the life time of the object. That is, when the object is finalized, the closure is invalidated by calling g_closure_invalidate() on it, in order to prevent invocations of the closure with a finalized (nonexisting) object. Also, g_object_ref() and g_object_unref() are added as marshal guards to the closure , to ensure that an extra reference count is held on object during invocation of the closure . Usually, this function will be called on closures that use this object as closure data.

refsect2.title: g_object_run_dispose ()
refsect2.para: Releases all references to other objects. This can be used to break reference cycles.
This function should only be called from object system implementations.

refsect2.title: G_OBJECT_WARN_INVALID_PROPERTY_ID()
refsect2.para: This macro should be used to emit a standard warning about unexpected properties in set_property() and get_property() implementations.

entry.para: the GObject on which set_property() or get_property() was called
the numeric id of the property

refsect2.title: g_weak_ref_init ()
refsect2.para: Initialise a non-statically-allocated GWeakRef.
This function also calls g_weak_ref_set() with object on the freshly-initialised weak reference.

This function should always be matched with a call to g_weak_ref_clear(). It is not necessary to use this function for a GWeakRef in static storage because it will already be properly initialised. Just use g_weak_ref_set() directly.

entry.para: uninitialized or empty location for a weak reference.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.32

refsect2.title: g_weak_ref_clear ()
refsect2.para: Frees resources associated with a non-statically-allocated GWeakRef. After this call, the GWeakRef is left in an undefined state.
You should only call this on a GWeakRef that previously had g_weak_ref_init() called on it.

entry.para: location of a weak reference, which may be empty.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.32

refsect2.title: g_weak_ref_get ()
refsect2.para: If weak_ref is not empty, atomically acquire a strong reference to the object it points to, and return that reference.
This function is needed because of the potential race between taking the pointer value and g_object_ref() on it, if the object was losing its last reference at the same time in a different thread.
The caller should release the resulting reference in the usual way, by using g_object_unref().

entry.para: location of a weak reference to a GObject.

refsect3.title: Returns
refsect3.para: the object pointed to by weak_ref , or NULL if it was empty.

refsect2.para: Since: 2.32

refsect2.title: g_weak_ref_set ()
refsect2.para: Change the object to which weak_ref points, or set it to NULL.
You must own a strong reference on object while calling this function.
Since: 2.32

refsect2.title: struct GObject
refsect2.para: All the fields in the GObject structure are private to the GObject implementation and should never be accessed directly.

refsect2.title: struct GObjectClass
refsect2.para: The class structure for the GObject type.

entry.para: the constructor function is called by g_object_new() to complete the object initialization after all the construction properties are set. The first thing a constructor implementation must do is chain up to the constructor of the parent class. Overriding constructor should be rarely needed, e.g. to handle construct properties, or to implement singletons.

the generic setter for all properties of this type. Should be overridden for every type with properties. If implementations of set_property don't emit property change notification explicitly, this will be done implicitly by the type system. However, if the notify signal is emitted explicitly, the type system will not emit it a second time.
the generic getter for all properties of this type. Should be overridden for every type with properties.

the dispose function is supposed to drop all references to other objects, but keep the instance otherwise intact, so that client method invocations still work. It may be run multiple times (due to reference loops). Before returning, dispose should chain up to the dispose method of the parent class.
instance finalization function, should finish the finalization of the instance begun in dispose and chain up to the finalize method of the parent class.
emits property change notification for a bunch of properties. Overriding dispatch_properties_changed should be rarely needed.
the class closure for the notify signal

the constructed function is called by g_object_new() as the final step of the object creation process. At the point of the call, all construction properties have been set on the object. The purpose of this call is to allow for object initialisation steps that can only be performed after construction properties have been set. constructed implementors should chain up to the constructed call of their parent class to allow it to complete its initialisation.

refsect2.title: struct GObjectConstructParam
refsect2.para: The GObjectConstructParam struct is an auxiliary structure used to hand GParamSpec/GValue pairs to the constructor of a GObjectClass.

entry.para: the GParamSpec of the construct parameter
the value to set the parameter to

refsect2.condition: deprecated:2.54: This type is not introspectable.
refsect2.title: struct GParameter

warning.para: GParameter has been deprecated since version 2.54 and should not be used in newly-written code.

refsect2.para: The GParameter struct is an auxiliary structure used to hand parameter name/value pairs to g_object_newv().

refsect2.title: GInitiallyUnowned
refsect2.para: All the fields in the GInitiallyUnowned structure are private to the GInitiallyUnowned implementation and should never be accessed directly.

refsect2.title: GInitiallyUnownedClass
refsect2.para: The class structure for the GInitiallyUnowned type.

refsect2.title: G_TYPE_INITIALLY_UNOWNED
refsect2.para: The type for GInitiallyUnowned.

refsect2.title: GWeakRef
refsect2.para: A structure containing a weak reference to a GObject. It can either be empty (i.e. point to NULL), or point to an object for as long as at least one "strong" reference to that object exists. Before the object's GObjectClass.dispose method is called, every GWeakRef associated with becomes empty (i.e. points to NULL).
Like GValue, GWeakRef can be statically allocated, stack- or heap-allocated, or embedded in larger structures.

Unlike g_object_weak_ref() and g_object_add_weak_pointer(), this weak reference is thread-safe: converting a weak pointer to a reference is atomic with respect to invalidation of weak pointers to destroyed objects.

If the object's GObjectClass.dispose method results in additional references to the object being held, any GWeakRefs taken before it was disposed will continue to point to NULL. If GWeakRefs are taken after the object is disposed and re-referenced, they will continue to point to it until its refcount goes back to zero, at which point they too will be invalidated.

refsect2.title: The notify signal
refsect2.para: The notify signal is emitted on an object when one of its properties has its value set through g_object_set_property(), g_object_set(), et al.

Note that getting this signal doesnt itself guarantee that the value of the property has actually changed. When it is emitted is determined by the derived GObject class. If the implementor did not create the property with G_PARAM_EXPLICIT_NOTIFY, then any call to g_object_set_property() results in ::notify being emitted, even if the new value is the same as the old. If they did pass G_PARAM_EXPLICIT_NOTIFY, then this signal is emitted only when they explicitly call g_object_notify() or g_object_notify_by_pspec(), and common practice is to do that only when the value has actually changed.
This signal is typically used to obtain change notification for a single property, by specifying the property name as a detail in the g_signal_connect() call, like this:
It is important to note that you must use canonical parameter names as detail strings for the notify signal.

entry.para: the object which received the signal.
the GParamSpec of the property which changed.

entry.simpara: user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.para: Flags: No Hooks
